a suspect linked to the state's largest wildfire this year, which began when a burning car was pushed into a gully. Fire personnel are prioritizing evacuations a"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Boise, Idaho"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Health/Public_Health_and_Safety/Emergency_Services", "label": "dmoz/Health/Public Health and Safety/Emergency Services", "wgt": 58}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Emergency_Preparation", "label": "dmoz/Home/Emergency Preparation", "wgt": 85}, {"uri": "dmoz/Home/Emergency_Preparation/Safety", "label": "dmoz/Home/Emergency Preparation/Safety", "wgt": 77}, {"uri": "news/Environment", "label": "news/Environment", "wgt": 69}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 84}, "sentiment": -0.1607843137254902, "breakingScore": 0.2571758607419794}
{"uri": "2024-07-433578563", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:07:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:07:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:44:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/25/wildfires-prompt-california-evacuations-as-crews-battle-oregon-and-idaho-fires-stoked-by-lightning/", "title": "Wildfires prompt California evacuations as crews battle Oregon and Idaho fires stoked by lightning", "body": "BOISE, Idaho (AP) -- Rapidly growing wildfires prompted evacuations in Northern California on Thursday, a day after powerful winds and lightning strikes in Oregon and Idaho cut power and stoked fires, including one in Oregon that was the largest active blaze in the United States. Another fast-moving wildfire forced thousands to abandon a town in Canada.\n\nEvacuations were ordered in California's Butte and Tehama counties as crews battled a fire reported near Chico just before 3 p.m. Wednesday. The blaze, dubbed the Park Fire, quickly spread from about 10 square miles (26 square kilometers) to more than 70 square miles (180 square kilometers) and was only 3% contained early Thursday, according to CAL FIRE. The cause was under investigation.\n\nFire personnel were focusing on evacuations and defending structures while using bulldozers to build containment lines. No deaths or damage to structures had been reported, CAL FIRE/ Butte County Fire Department said in a late Wednesday update.\n\nFires in several western states and Canada have forced some areas to declare air quality alerts or advisories as skies filled with smoke and haze. In the Canadian Rockies' largest national park, a fast-moving wildfire this week hit the town of Jasper, forcing thousands to flee and causing significant damage.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nKotek said she had deployed the National Guard to the region. The Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities at risk.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small bulldozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was already burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire had come down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire was spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square miles (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Lisa Baumann contributed from Bellingham, Washington and Martha Bellisle contributed from Seattle.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-433382681", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:56:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:56:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T09:44:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/idaho/articles/2024-07-25/wildfires-prompt-california-evacuations-as-crews-battle-oregon-and-idaho-fires-stoked-by-lightning", "title": "Wildfires Prompt California Evacuations as Crews Battle Oregon and Idaho Fires Stoked by Lightning", "body": "BOISE, Idaho (AP) -- Wildfires prompted evacuations in Northern California amid a rapidly growing wildfire Thursday, a day after powerful winds and lightning strikes from thunderstorms rattled eastern Oregon and Idaho, cutting power and stoking fires, including one in Oregon that was the largest active blaze in the United States. Another fast-moving wildfire forced thousands to abandon a town in Canada.\n\nEvacuations were ordered in California's Butte and Tehama counties as crews battled a fire reported near Chico just before 3 p.m. Wednesday. The blaze, dubbed the Park Fire, quickly spread from about 10 square miles (26 square kilometers) to more than 70 square miles (180 square kilometers) and was only 3% contained early Thursday, according to CAL FIRE. The cause was under investigation.\n\nFire personnel were focusing on evacuations and defending structures while using bulldozers to build containment lines. No deaths or damage to structures had been reported, CAL FIRE/ Butte County Fire Department said in a late Wednesday update.\n\nFires in several western states and Canada have forced some areas to declare air quality alerts or advisories as skies filled with smoke and haze. In the Canadian Rockies' largest national park, a fast-moving wildfire this week hit the town of Jasper, forcing thousands to flee and causing significant damage.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nKotek said she had deployed the National Guard to the region. The Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities at risk.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small bulldozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was already burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire had come down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire was spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square miles (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Lisa Baumann contributed from Bellingham, Washington and Martha Bellisle contributed from Seattle.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. Another fast-moving wildfire forced thousands to abandon a town in Canada.Evacuations were ordered in California's Butte and Tehama counties as crews battled a fire reported near Chico just before 3 p.m. Wednesday. The blaze, dubbed the Park Fire, quickly spread from about 10 square miles (26 square kilometers) to more than 70 square miles (180 square kilometers) and was only 3% contained early Thursday, according to CAL FIRE. The cause was under investigation.Fire personnel were focusing on evacuations and defending structures while using bulldozers to build containment lines. No deaths or damage to structures had been reported, CAL FIRE/ Butte County Fire Department said in a late Wednesday update.Fires in several western states and Canada have forced some areas to declare air quality alerts or advisories as skies filled with smoke and haze. In the Canadian Rockies' largest national park, a fast-moving wildfire this week hit the town of Jasper, forcing thousands to flee and causing significant damage.The Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"Kotek said she had deployed the National Guard to the region. The Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities at risk.The nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.The fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small bulldozer to keep it away from the house, she said.Since their property was already burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire had come down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"The National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.Wind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.The major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.More than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.A fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.Evacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire was spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square miles (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.The smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.Patrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"Nauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.Mike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. "dmoz/Home/Emergency Preparation/Safety", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Environment", "label": "news/Environment", "wgt": 88}], "image": null, "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9761049", "eventUri": "eng-9761049", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.3098039215686275, "wgt": 234, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-433395460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:07:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:07:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:44:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.maryvilleforum.com/news/state_news/wildfires-prompt-california-evacuations-as-crews-battle-oregon-and-idaho-fires-stoked-by-lightning/article_37248d29-1462-5df5-b057-868fab3bb88e.html", "title": "Wildfires prompt California evacuations as crews battle Oregon and Idaho fires stoked by lightning", "body": "Rapidly growing wildfires have prompted evacuations in Northern and Southern California, and powerful winds and lightning strikes are rattling eastern Oregon and Idaho, cutting power and stoking fires\n\nBOISE, Idaho (AP) -- Wildfires prompted evacuations in Northern California amid a rapidly growing wildfire Thursday, a day after powerful winds and lightning strikes from thunderstorms rattled eastern Oregon and Idaho, cutting power and stoking fires, including one in Oregon that was the largest active blaze in the United States. Another fast-moving wildfire forced thousands to abandon a town in Canada.\n\nEvacuations were ordered in California's Butte and Tehama counties as crews battled a fire reported near Chico just before 3 p.m. Wednesday. The blaze, dubbed the Park Fire, quickly spread from about 10 square miles (26 square kilometers) to more than 70 square miles (180 square kilometers) and was only 3% contained early Thursday, according to CAL FIRE. The cause was under investigation.\n\nFire personnel were focusing on evacuations and defending structures while using bulldozers to build containment lines. No deaths or damage to structures had been reported, CAL FIRE/ Butte County Fire Department said in a late Wednesday update.\n\nFires in several western states and Canada have forced some areas to declare air quality alerts or advisories as skies filled with smoke and haze. In the Canadian Rockies' largest national park, a fast-moving wildfire this week hit the town of Jasper, forcing thousands to flee and causing significant damage.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nKotek said she had deployed the National Guard to the region. The Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities at risk.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small bulldozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was already burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire had come down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire was spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square miles (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lisa Baumann contributed from Bellingham, Washington and Martha Bellisle contributed from Seattle.", "source": {"uri": "maryvilleforum.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Maryville Forum"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243243705", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:41:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:41:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:40:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/wildfires-prompt-california-evacuations-as-crews-battle-fires-in-oregon-idaho", "title": "Wildfires prompt California evacuations as crews battle fires in Oregon, Idaho", "body": "BOISE, Idaho (AP) -- Rapidly growing wildfires prompted evacuations in Northern California on Thursday, a day after powerful winds and lightning strikes in Oregon and Idaho cut power and stoked fires, including one in Oregon that was the largest active blaze in the United States. Another fast-moving wildfire forced thousands to abandon a town in Canada.\n\nREAD MORE: Inland counties top disaster list as extreme weather becomes more frequent\n\nEvacuations were ordered in California's Butte and Tehama counties as crews battled a fire reported near Chico just before 3 p.m. Wednesday. The blaze, dubbed the Park Fire, quickly spread from about 10 square miles (26 square kilometers) to more than 70 square miles (180 square kilometers) and was only 3 percent contained early Thursday, according to CAL FIRE. The cause was under investigation.\n\nFire personnel were focusing on evacuations and defending structures while using bulldozers to build containment lines. No deaths or damage to structures had been reported, CAL FIRE/ Butte County Fire Department said in a late Wednesday update.\n\nFires in several western states and Canada have forced some areas to declare air quality alerts or advisories as skies filled with smoke and haze. In the Canadian Rockies' largest national park, a fast-moving wildfire this week hit the town of Jasper, forcing thousands to flee and causing significant damage.\n\nREAD MORE: California officials report state's first wildfire death of the 2024 season\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nKotek said she had deployed the National Guard to the region. The Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities at risk.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small bulldozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was already burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire had come down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire was spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square miles (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5 percent contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lisa Baumann contributed from {"uri": "2024-07-432829540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "05:20:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T05:20:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T04:52:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/oregon-fire-becomes-the-biggest-blaze-in-the-us-worsened-by-thunderstorms-and-strong-winds/", "title": "Oregon fire becomes the biggest blaze in the US, worsened by thunderstorms and strong winds - Internewscast Journal", "body": "BOISE, Idaho (AP) -- Powerful winds and hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms rattled eastern Oregon and Idaho Wednesday afternoon, cutting power and stoking fires, including one in Oregon that is already the largest active blaze in the nation.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nShe said she had deployed the National Guard to the region.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small dozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire came down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nA flash flood warning was issued for the Cow Valley burn scar in Eastern Oregon at about 8 p.m. Wednesday and was expected to last until 10:30 p.m., said Les Colin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, Idaho. A strong thunderstorm moved into a burned area that is especially susceptible to flooding, he said. No homes are in the area but Interstate 84 runs close by.\n\nThe Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities that could be threatened by wildfires on Wednesday.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire is spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square mile (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Lisa Baumann contributed from Bellingham, Washington and Martha Bellisle contributed from Seattle.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243192410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:06:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:06:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:05:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/ap-huntington-idaho-boise-northern-california-b2585843.html", "title": "Wildfires prompt California evacuations as crews battle Oregon and Idaho fires stoked by lightning", "body": "Our mission is to deliver unbiased, fact-based reporting that holds power to account and exposes the truth.\n\nWhether $5 or $50, every contribution counts.\n\nSupport us to deliver journalism without an agenda.\n\nWildfires prompted evacuations in Northern California amid a rapidly growing wildfire Thursday, a day after powerful winds and lightning strikes from thunderstorms rattled eastern Oregon and Idaho, cutting power and stoking fires, including one in Oregon that was the largest active blaze in the United States. Another fast-moving wildfire forced thousands to abandon a town in Canada.\n\nEvacuations were ordered in California's Butte and Tehama counties as crews battled a fire reported near Chico just before 3 p.m. Wednesday. The blaze, dubbed the Park Fire, quickly spread from about 10 square miles (26 square kilometers) to more than 70 square miles (180 square kilometers) and was only 3% contained early Thursday, according to CAL FIRE. The cause was under investigation.\n\nFire personnel were focusing on evacuations and defending structures while using bulldozers to build containment lines. No deaths or damage to structures had been reported, CAL FIRE/ Butte County Fire Department said in a late Wednesday update.\n\nFires in several western states and Canada have forced some areas to declare air quality alerts or advisories as skies filled with smoke and haze. In the Canadian Rockies' largest national park, a fast-moving wildfire this week hit the town of Jasper, forcing thousands to flee and causing significant damage.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nKotek said she had deployed the National Guard to the region. The Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities at risk.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small bulldozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was already burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire had come down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire was spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square miles (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Lisa Baumann contributed from Bellingham, Washington and Martha Bellisle contributed from Seattle.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-432894779", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:39:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:39:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T06:39:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://globalnation.inquirer.net/243598/oregon-fire-is-the-largest-burning-in-us", "title": "Oregon fire is the largest burning in US", "body": "BOISE, Idaho -- Oregon currently has the largest active blaze in the United States, and powerful winds and hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms affecting the eastern part of the state and Idaho on Wednesday afternoon were exacerbating the fire.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday, July 24. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nShe said she had deployed the National Guard to the region.\n\nREAD: Western US faces wildfires as millions under heat warnings\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small dozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire came down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nA flash flood warning was issued for the Cow Valley burn scar in Eastern Oregon at about 8 p.m. Wednesday and was expected to last until 10:30 p.m., said Les Colin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, Idaho. A strong thunderstorm moved into a burned area that is especially susceptible to flooding, he said. No homes are in the area but Interstate 84 runs close by.\n\nREAD: Wildfires send thousands fleeing from Canadian Rockies' largest national park\n\nThe Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities that could be threatened by wildfires on Wednesday.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire is spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. {"uri": "8243182102", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:59:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:59:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:58:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/498607/Wildfires-prompt-California-evacuations-as-crews-battle-Oregon-and-Idaho-fires-stoked-by-lightning", "title": "Wildfires prompt California evacuations as crews battle Oregon and Idaho fires stoked by lightning - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press The sun sets behind the mountains obscured by wildfire smoke from blazes in the American West and provinces of western Canada late Wednesday, July 24, 2024, in Denver. (AP Photo/David Zalubowski)\n\nWildfires prompted evacuations in Northern California amid a rapidly growing wildfire Thursday, a day after powerful winds and lightning strikes from thunderstorms rattled eastern Oregon and Idaho, cutting power and stoking fires, including one in Oregon that was the largest active blaze in the United States. Another fast-moving wildfire forced thousands to abandon a town in Canada.\n\nEvacuations were ordered in California's Butte and Tehama counties as crews battled a fire reported near Chico just before 3 p.m. Wednesday. The blaze, dubbed the Park Fire, quickly spread from about 10 square miles (26 square kilometers) to more than 70 square miles (180 square kilometers) and was only 3% contained early Thursday, according to CAL FIRE. The cause was under investigation.\n\nFire personnel were focusing on evacuations and defending structures while using bulldozers to build containment lines. No deaths or damage to structures had been reported, CAL FIRE/ Butte County Fire Department said in a late Wednesday update.\n\nFires in several western states and Canada have forced some areas to declare air quality alerts or advisories as skies filled with smoke and haze. In the Canadian Rockies' largest national park, a fast-moving wildfire this week hit the town of Jasper, forcing thousands to flee and causing significant damage.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nKotek said she had deployed the National Guard to the region. The Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities at risk.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small bulldozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was already burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire had come down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire was spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square miles (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": Thunderstorms and high winds are exacerbating it", "body": "The National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility.\n\nPowerful winds and hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms rattled eastern Oregon and Idaho Wednesday afternoon, cutting power and stoking fires, including one in Oregon that is already the largest active blaze in the nation.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nShe said she had deployed the National Guard to the region.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small dozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire came down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nA flash flood warning was issued for the Cow Valley burn scar in Eastern Oregon at about 8 p.m. Wednesday and was expected to last until 10:30 p.m., said Les Colin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, Idaho. A strong thunderstorm moved into a burned area that is especially susceptible to flooding, he said. No homes are in the area but Interstate 84 runs close by.\n\nThe Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities that could be threatened by wildfires on Wednesday.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire is spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square mile (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "nbcmiami.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8242554743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:21:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:21:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:20:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/07/25/world/americas-emea/oregon-fire-is-the-largest-burning-in-the-us/1959785", "title": "Oregon fire is the largest burning in the US", "body": "BOISE, Idaho -- Powerful winds and hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms rattled eastern Oregon and Idaho Wednesday afternoon, cutting power and stoking fires, including one in Oregon that is already the largest active blaze in the nation.\n\nThe Durkee Fire, burning near the Oregon-Idaho border about 130 miles (209 kilometers) west of Boise, Idaho, caused the closure of a stretch of Interstate 84 again Wednesday. Amid rapidly forming storms in the afternoon, the blaze crossed the interstate near the town of Huntington, home to about 500 people. It also merged with the Cow Valley Fire, another large blaze that had been burning nearby, Gov. Tina Kotek said.\n\n\"The wildfires in Eastern Oregon have scaled up quickly,\" Kotek said in a news release Wednesday evening, calling it a dynamic situation. \"We are facing strong erratic winds over the region that could impact all fires. Rain is not getting through. Some communities do not have power.\"\n\nShe said she had deployed the National Guard to the region.\n\nThe nearly 420-square-mile (1,088-square-kilometer) blaze had prompted the evacuation of Huntington on Sunday, and on Wednesday city officials posted on Facebook that people remaining in town, especially those with \"major health issues,\" needed to leave their homes because of wildfire smoke and the lack of power. City officials also said Wednesday that gas service to residents had been shut off until the evacuation orders are lifted.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nThe fire approached Alison Oszman's home in Rye Valley, a small ranching area north of Huntington, last week, but they were able to protect their property with the help of Bureau of Land Management firefighters and neighbors, using small tanker trucks and shovels. They used a small dozer to keep it away from the house, she said.\n\nSince their property was burned and safe, her neighbor moved his horses and cattle over as the fire moved toward his ranch, she said. On Wednesday night, Oszman went to check his property and found that the fire came down a steep hillside and threatened his home.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I went and parked our truck out in the field just in case those big trees by his house caught fire,\" she said. \"I was making sure sparks didn't land in the dirt or the dry grass. But as the fire passed his house, it started raining.\" The rain helped the firefighters get on top of the blaze.\n\n\"It was pretty scary but everything seemed to fall into place,\" she said. \"Everybody helped everybody. It was actually pretty amazing for how crummy it really was.\"\n\nThe National Weather Service in Boise said the storms were capable of producing wind gusts up to 70 mph with blowing dust reducing visibility. A storm about 44 miles (71 kilometers) northwest of Huntington near Baker City on Wednesday afternoon had recorded a wind gust of 66 mph (106 kph), the weather service said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWind, lightning and heavy rain fell that could cause flash flooding and debris flows in recently burned areas, authorities said. Flash flood warnings were issued for Huntington and in a nearby burn scar area.\n\nA flash flood warning was issued for the Cow Valley burn scar in Eastern Oregon at about 8 p.m. Wednesday and was expected to last until 10:30 p.m., said Les Colin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, Idaho. A strong thunderstorm moved into a burned area that is especially susceptible to flooding, he said. No homes are in the area but Interstate 84 runs close by.\n\nThe Oregon State Fire Marshal's office also mobilized nearly 500 firefighters to help protect communities that could be threatened by wildfires on Wednesday.\n\nThe major electricity utility in the region, Idaho Power, warned customers to prepare for possible outages, and by late Wednesday afternoon, nearly 7,000 customers were without electricity, the utility said. The utility also cut power to customers in the Boise foothills and other nearby areas, citing extreme weather and wildfire risk.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMore than 60 significant fires are burning in Oregon and Washington alone, and Oregon has been plagued with hundreds of lightning strikes from thunderstorms in recent days that have started new blazes in bone-dry vegetation.\n\nA fire in southern California also was moving fast and threatening homes.\n\nEvacuation orders were in effect Wednesday night in San Diego County after a wildfire began to spread fast near the San Diego and Riverside county line. Fire officials say the Grove Fire is spreading southeast through steep and challenging terrain. The fire grew to 1.3 square mile (3.4 square kilometers) within a few hours but was 5% contained just before 8 p.m., Cal Fire said on the social media platform X.\n\nThe smoke from the Durkee Fire in Oregon was choking the air in Boise and beyond. An air quality warning was in effect for the entire region on Wednesday.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nPatrick Nauman, the owner of Weiser Classic Candy in the small town of Weiser, Idaho, near the Oregon border, said driving into town Wednesday morning was \"like driving into a fog bank, because it's so thick and low to the road.\"\n\nNauman's shop is on the main intersection in town and is typically a popular spot to stop for lunch or a sugar fix, but customer traffic has dropped by half in the past few days as thick smoke and triple-digit temperatures dogged the region.\n\n\"Yesterday you could smell it, taste it, it just kind of hung in the back of your throat,\" Nauman said of the smoke.\n\nMike Cantin, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Boise, said cooler air moving into the region Wednesday evening could stoke the Durkee and other fires. A red flag warning was in effect, and the area has been suffering through a heat wave, including many days over 100 degrees Fahrenheit (38 degrees Celsius).\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"With these winds showing up today, every little spark could get out of hand very easily. It could be a really hazardous situation very fast,\" Cantin said. \"Don't light anything on fire, and be very careful around grass.\"", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news",
